awd_titl_txt: Toward Solving Cosmic Particle Mysteries with Neutrinos and Gamma Rays
awd_abstract_narration:
This award funds the research activities of Professor Kohta Murase at the Pennsylvania State University. 

A new frontier in particle astrophysics has just opened up with the recent discovery of high-energy extra-terrestrial neutrinos by the the Gigaton-scale neutrino detector known as IceCube.   Neutrinos are ghostlike neutral particles which can escape from dense regions in the Universe;   because they interact so weakly with other forms of matter, they arrive undeflected at Earth and thus tend to point directly back to the distant astrophysical sources that produced them.  The origin of these high-energy neutrinos recently discovered by IceCube is a new mystery in the field, and solving this problem would allow us not only to understand the microphysics and mechanisms of the sources but also to obtain important clues about an old mystery, the origin of cosmic rays.  More general, this discovery allows us to utilize neutrinos as probes of neutrino properties, dark matter, and other forms of fundamental physics.  A major goal of Professor Murase's research is to address these new and old problems through combinations of data coming not only from neutrinos but also from gamma rays, through theoretical calculations of particle production and propagation.  This research is interdisciplinary, including topics in astrophysics and particle physics and connecting theoretical ideas directly to experimental and observational data.  As a result, this research will advance the national interest by promoting the progress of fundamental science.  This project is also envisioned to have significant broader impacts.   It will involve and thereby provide training to graduate students involved in this research, and key concepts of particle astrophysics will be disseminated among educators at high schools and community colleges.

More technically, one of the key ingredients in this research is the strategic multi-messenger approach in which predictions for different astroparticles (neutrinos, gamma rays, and cosmic rays) are confronted with data.  With sophisticated calculations including all relevant microphysical processes, the PI will test various models for the astroparticle origins and extract fundamental insights into the source physics of extreme astrophysical objects.  The multi-messenger connection among the measured neutrino, gamma-ray, and cosmic-ray backgrounds will be examined, and source classes of cosmic-ray accelerators that cannot be directly probed by gamma rays will also be studied.  The results of this study should be useful for the design of proposed next-generation neutrino and gamma-ray detectors.

por.por_cntn:
Professor Murase worked to address new questions in astroparticle physics, which have been brought by the observations of high-energy cosmic neutrinos with the Gigaton-scale neutrino detector known as IceCube. 

One of the goals is to reveal the main origin of IceCube neutrinos. Using the neutrino and gamma-ray data, Professor Murase and his collaborators derived general constraints on the candidate sources. In particular, rare and bright classes of the sources such as blazars - active galaxies whose black-hole jet points to the Earth - are strongly constrained. The results are encouraging because they suggest that the dominant sources of the IceCube neutrinos can be identified by next-generation neutrino detectors such as IceCube-Gen2.       

Professor Murase aims to understand the connections between neutrinos and gamma rays. He investigated models of cosmic-ray reservoirs, in which cosmic rays produce neutrinos and gamma rays via interactions with radiation and matter while they are confined in magnetized environments for a long time. The candidate sources include star-forming galaxies with active galaxies or galaxy mergers, as well as galaxy clusters and groups with black-hole jets. In particular, Murase's team sought for unified models to explain diffuse fluxes of high-energy neutrinos, gamma rays, and ultrahigh-energy cosmic rays. By exploiting detailed numerical simulations, the team found that black-hole jets embedded in galaxy clusters can naturally explain all the three messenger data. In addition, Murase gave quantitative estimates on energetics of these three cosmic messenger particles, and showed that they are all comparable. Luminosity densities of various source populations were also evaluated, which can be used for revealing the multi-messenger connection. 
 
Professor Murase also investigated high-energy neutrino emissions from various classes of transient sources, including gamma-ray bursts and double neutron star mergers. Some of the predictions have been used by experimental groups for searching coincident events of high-energy neutrinos and gravitational waves. The results suggest that future observations will give us fundamental insights into source physics of extreme astrophysical objects. Murase also developed a new time-dependent code to calculate high-energy neutrino and gamma-ray emission, and applied it to supernovae. The results gave the first quantitative predictions for high-energy neutrinos, showing that the detection from the next Galactic supernova is promising.  

Professor Murase also utilized neutrinos as probes of neutrino properties and dark matter. In particular, Murase's team placed new neutrino and gamma-ray limits on decaying dark matter. He also proposed a new method to probe neutrino-neutrino and neutrino-dark matter interactions that are often expected in particle physics models beyond the Standard Model. 

The accomplished research significantly involved graduate students and postdoctoral researches, and thereby provided them with training. In addition, some of the concepts in particle astrophysics were disseminated among educators at high schools and community colleges. In collaboration with the Center for Science and the Schools (CSATS), a Penn State center specializing in K-12 STEM outreach, Professor Murase had one-day workshop for K12 teachers. Murase's team developed a simple python script to understand sky coordinates and see spatial correlations between high-energy neutrinos and supernovae. The K12 teachers learned the basics of supernovae and cosmic particles, and their roles in the Universe. 

Professor Murase gave invited talks at various international conferences, and presented the results obtained by this research. Some of the accomplishments were highlighted by several news media. He was also interviewed by science writers, and the articles were read by general audience outside the community.
